title: Yet Another Array Problem
statementHtml:
You are given an integer nn and an array aa of length nn.

Find the smallest integer xx (2≤x≤10182≤x≤1018) such that there exists an index ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n) with gcdgcd∗∗(ai,x)=1(ai,x)=1. If no such xx exists within the range [2,1018][2,1018], output −1−1.

∗∗gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of integers xx and yy.
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains a single integer tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104) — the number of test cases.

Each of the following tt test cases consists of two lines:

The first line contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1051≤n≤105) — the length of the array.

The second line contains nn space-separated integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018).

It is guaranteed that the total sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 105105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer: the smallest xx (2≤x≤10182≤x≤1018) such that there exists an index ii with gcd(ai,x)=1gcd(ai,x)=1. If there is no such xx in the range [2,1018][2,1018], print −1−1.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, gcd(2,1)=1gcd(2,1)=1, which is the smallest number satisfying the condition.

In the second test case:

  • gcd(2,6)=2gcd(2,6)=2, gcd(2,12)=2gcd(2,12)=2, so 22 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(3,6)=3gcd(3,6)=3, gcd(3,12)=3gcd(3,12)=3, so 33 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(4,6)=2gcd(4,6)=2, gcd(4,12)=4gcd(4,12)=4, so 44 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(5,6)=1gcd(5,6)=1, so the answer is 55.

In the third test case:

  • gcd(2,24)=2gcd(2,24)=2, gcd(2,120)=2gcd(2,120)=2, gcd(2,210)=2gcd(2,210)=2, so 22 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(3,24)=3gcd(3,24)=3, gcd(3,120)=3gcd(3,120)=3, gcd(3,210)=3gcd(3,210)=3, so 33 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(4,24)=4gcd(4,24)=4, gcd(4,120)=4gcd(4,120)=4, gcd(4,210)=2gcd(4,210)=2, so 44 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(5,24)=1gcd(5,24)=1, so the answer is 55.

In the fourth test case:

  • gcd(2,2)=2gcd(2,2)=2, gcd(2,4)=2gcd(2,4)=2, gcd(2,6)=2gcd(2,6)=2, gcd(2,10)=2gcd(2,10)=2, so 22 cannot be the answer.
  • gcd(3,2)=1gcd(3,2)=1, so the answer is 33.
tutorialHtml:
Let's first try to prove our first claim. Let x be the answer and p the smallest prime divisor of x. gcd(x,ai)= pmin(e1,e21)1⋅pmin(e2,e22)2⋅…⋅pmin(ek,e2k)i=1, where pi and ei are prime factorization of x and p2i and e2i are that of ai. Since gcd(x,ai)=1, for each i either ei=0 or e2i=0 should hold. If p is prime divisor of x, then ei≥1 for pi=p, thus e2i=0 must hold. This implies that gcd(p,ai)=1. So we will focus only on prime numbers.

Since ai≡0 (mod x) for each i, if x does not satisfy the condition, the problem is asking for the smallest x. The answer will not be big, because 2⋅3⋅5⋅7…⋅53 >1018. Thus, it is sufficient to check the first prime numbers up to 53 using brute force (inclusive).
